abstracts.cdata!:
The Chimborazo Development Investment
            Project for Ecuador received a satisfactory outcome rating
            with moderate risk to development outcome. The Bank received
            a moderately satisfactory performance rating while the
            Borrower was rated satisfactory. Two restructurings took
            place during this project. The first restricting was a level
            two restructuring that: (i) adjusted Results Framework to
            better reflect project activities; (ii) adjusted the
            location of roads rehabilitation segments; reallocated
            US$790,000 of loan proceeds to reflect actual costs at
            sub-component level; updated project financing plan; and,
            changed the name of the Borrower. The second restructuring
            was also a level two restructuring which extended the
            closing date by nine months to permit completion of several
            large irrigation subprojects. For budgetary reason, team
            leaders withdrew certain road segments targeted for
            financing under Sub-component 1.2 and substitutes would be
            needed. Roads eligible for Central Government financing
            required final technical/feasibility studies. The project
            generated several lesson including: (1) the project thrived
            in large part because of a dynamic, well-connected leader
            who championed its goals, owned the methodology, understood
            the projects strategic context, saw the longer-term
            potential for his province of working successfully with the
            Bank. (2) Successful monitoring and evaluation performance
            requires complete buy-in to a coherent progression of
            research/reporting throughout, on the part of both the
            Borrower and the Bank teams. (3) The indirect benefits of a
            well-conceived investment operation can be considerable and
            important. In this case, the strong emphasis on local
            institutional capacity-building based on standards, rules,
            rights and responsibilities had a marked impact on reducing
            conflict among irrigator communities, liberating them to
            focus on agricultural advancement rather than the constant
            and corrosive struggle for water. (4) The design, content
            and delivery  including culturally appropriate social
            mobilization behind and communicating the desirability of
            change  along with reliable, continuous technical and
            financial support, market intelligence, and productive
            organization and entrepreneurship, are basic pre-requisites
            to secure farmer buy-in.
